fields.answer: In the “Data Layers” window, click on the name of the data layer to view a brief description of the data.   Click on the name of the data layer again to remove the description.
fields.question: How do I find out information about a data layer (e.g. where it came from)?

fields.answer: You must be logged in to change your password. Once logged in, click on the “Change Password Link” at the upper right hand corner of the screen and follow the instructions.
fields.question: How can I change my password?

fields.answer: If the data layer is represented by symbols (such as an animal figure), click on the individual point that you wish to identify and a small balloon will display the attributes for that point.
fields.question: How do I find information about features within a data layer?

fields.answer:
There is currently an out-of-process plugin (OOPP) issue with Google Earth and Firefox 5.0. This appears to be related to the displaying of kml description balloons.

The solution is to do the following:

  • 1. Open a new Tab and type “about:config” is the address bar
  • 2. If applicable, click “I’ll be careful, I promise”
  • 3. Right click on some white space in the about:config page and select “New” then “boolean”
  • 4. Type in “dom.ipc.plugins.enabled.npgeplugin.dll” then click “OK”
  • 5. Set value to “false” then click “OK”
  • 6. Restart your browser, and reload oregon.marinemap.org

Again, this is only applicable to Firefox users (version 5 and above), and we expect the folks at Google and/or Firefox to address this issue soon.
fields.question: I'm getting a Google Earth 'Internal Error' when using Firefox. What should I do?

fields.answer:
There are two ways to create a bookmark:

1. Create New -> Bookmark allows you to create and manage a bookmark (assign it a name, group it in folders with other shapes, share it with other users, grab and share the URL, etc).

2. From the Tools panel, you can create a Bookmark that will not be manageable under the My Shapes tab, but will still provide you with a URL that you can use at a later time or share with others.
fields.question: How can I capture the state of my data layers in a bookmark that can be viewed at a later date or shared with others?

fields.answer:
This is a very infrequent but present bug that has been noticed by some users. It occurs when your browser is unable to connect to Google Earth, and creates a stale link in the plugin's cache. You can fix this error by visiting the following link in your web browser: http://washington.marineplanning.org/media/common/fixtures/earthLayers.kml
You do not need to save or open the file, simply requesting the .kml will refresh the Google Earth cache.
fields.question: What should I do if i see an "Error Loading" message in the Data Layers sidebar?

fields.answer:
There are a few keyboard short-cuts and mouse clicks that can help you when navigating the map.

Mouse left click & hold: Drag the map around
Mouse right click and hold (or ctrl + left click): Fly into and around a set point smoothly
Mouse middle click and hold (or shift + left click): Move around a fixed point on the map
Mouse scroll wheel (or page up/down): Zoom in and out
Command: Moves your view around the current position
Arrow keps (or w,a,s,d): Moves the map around with a fixed view
n: Points you North
u: Returns your view to top-down looking
r: Points you north and returns your view to top-down looking
=: Slowly zooms in
fields.question: What are some keyboard commands to help me use the Marine Planner more efficiently?

fields.answer: If you are not yet logged in from a previous session, simply click the “sign in” button on the top right hand corner of the screen. Then click the link that says, “Forgot your password?” Enter your email address that you used to sign up for a Marine Planner account with and we will email you a new temporary password. If you have logged in previously, your browser may have remembered you and, therefore, you are still logged in. To retrieve your password, log out by signing out and then follow the instructions above.
fields.question: I have forgotten my password.  How can I find out what it is?

fields.answer: The performance of the Marine Planner application is primarily dependent on 3 things: your computer, connection speed, and choice of browser. The easiest of those three that you can change is your browser. On Windows, Mozilla Firefox and Google Chrome are both excellent choices. Microsoft Internet Explorer 8 is supported, but is noticeably slower than Chrome or Firefox. On a Mac, Safari is fastest followed by Firefox. Chrome on OSX does not currently support the Google Earth Plugin.
fields.question: How can I make the Marine Planner run faster on my computer?

fields.answer: Data layers are listed in the “Data Layers” section of the Marine Planner, which is visible at the top right hand corner of the left window pane, and looks like three sheets of paper stacked on top of each other. Data layers are organized into folders based on the theme of the data. Entire folders may be turned on for viewing, or the folder may be expanded using the small arrow to the left of the checkbox. To view a particular data layer or theme folder, click the checkbox to the left of the data layer name.
fields.question: How do I view a data layer?

fields.answer: Please send an email to help@marineplanning.org with a short description of your issue.
fields.question: Who should I contact if I have questions?

fields.answer:
Due to current limitations of the Google Earth plug-in, direct printing is not yet possible. In the meantime you may follow the operating system specific instructions below to create a screen shot, which may then be printed just like a picture.

In Apple OSX: The key combination Command-Shift-3 Takes a screenshot of the screen, and saves it as a file on the desktop. This can then be printed as a picture. See this link for more detailed information.

In Windows XP: The key combination Alt-Print Screen will copy the selected window to the clipboard as an image. You can then open up a program such as MS Paint or Adobe Photoshop and paste the clipboard to a blank template. At that point you can print the image directly or save a copy for later. See this link for more detailed information.

In Windows Vista & Windows 7: You can use the Snipping Tool to capture a screenshot. Open the Snipping Tool by clicking the Start button Picture of the Start button, clicking All Programs, clicking Accessories, and then clicking Snipping Tool. Click the arrow next to the New button, select a snip type from the menu, and then use your mouse to capture a snip. You can then save the copied image as a file and print from there. See this link for more detailed information.
fields.question: How do I print something from the Marine Planner?
